Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Korea
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Michael Jong Lee of the University of Washington to conduct a research project, entitled "Effect of game elements on learning for novice programmers," during the summer of 2012 at Yonsei University in Seoul, South Korea. The host scientist is Dr. Jinwoo Kim.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project lies in identifying how certain game elements affect learning outcomes in a programming computer game, creating better ways to incorporate or disguise tests within the game levels to reduce the stress of test-taking, and to provide better understanding of how different testing approaches to measure learning affects novice programmers. Outcomes may allow access to computer programming training to individuals or groups that are interested in programming who but do not have the resources to take a course, increase or maintain people's interest in science and technology by providing a low-barrier introduction into programming, and result in designs for educational software to evaluate player learning, and dispel the negative view of online games by demonstrating positive learning outcomes.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Both of the following projects were conducted as part of the the National Science Foundation’s East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI), which fosters collaboration between US graduate students and East Asian researchers. The host institution was the Human-Computer Interaction Lab at Yonsei University in Seoul, South Korea.

 

Project #1 Title: Effect of Game Elements on Learning for Novice Programmers

The purpose of this research was to learn how different game elements’ affects novices’ engagement using a custom-built online game designed to teach programming and debugging concepts. A small, controlled study of several participants playing different version of the game was conducted. Our results give insight into the effect of certain game elements on novices’ engagement with playing the game, with more playtime equating to increased exposure to the programming language and debugging tasks. In addition, cultural differences were observed in participants’ attitude towards the educational game. 

Results and data collected from these observations will be particularly useful in designing and integrating learning assessments into the game, while keeping the overall flow and enjoyability of the game intact. Since the game is designed to be an educational tool for novices to learn programming and debugging skills, including tests to assess their progress and measure learning outcomes is essential. The results from continued exploration in this area are specifically useful for the fields of computer science education and learning science.

Project #2 Title: Github Developers Use Rockstars to Overcome Overflow of News

The host lab provided access to a unique dataset tracking all the actions and connections of developers on a website called Github. This prompted research with the purpose of learning how developers on a collaborative programming site with social networking features (e.g. “following” projects or individuals) chose projects to work on. A tool was developed to help visualize and analyze the massive dataset, allowing us to identify code contribution patterns and a specific user-type within the data. Our results give insight into how extremely well-connected individuals (i.e. “rockstars”) may influence the projects that their followers find and ultimately work on.

The results of this project are potentially useful for the design of next-generation, online collaborative tools and spaces. Continued research in this area can draw from and expand current knowledge in the areas of human-computer interaction, software engineering, psychology, and design.
